pageProps.contentHtml:
Lp spaces

Let f∈L1(R)f \in L^1\p{\R}f∈L1(R). Show that the series

∑n=1∞1nf(x−n)\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} f\p{x - \sqrt{n}}n=1∑∞​n​1​f(x−n​)

converges absolutely for almost all x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R.
Solution.

Let k∈Nk \in \Nk∈N. Since everything is non-negative in the following, we may apply Fubini-Tonelli to obtain

∫kk+1∑n=1∞1n∣f(x−n)∣ dx=∑n=1∞1n∫kk+1∣f(x−n)∣ dx=∑n=1∞1n∫kk+1∣f(x−n)∣ dx(x↦x−n)=∑n=1∞1n∫k−nk+1−n∣f(x)∣ dx=∑n=1∞1n∫Rχ{k−n≤x≤k+1−n}∣f(x)∣ dx=∫R∣f(x)∣∑n=1∞1nχ{k−x≤n≤k+1−x} dx.\begin{aligned} \int_k^{k+1} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \abs{f\p{x - \sqrt{n}}} \,\diff{x} &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \int_k^{k+1} \abs{f\p{x - \sqrt{n}}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \int_k^{k+1} \abs{f\p{x - \sqrt{n}}} \,\diff{x} && \p{x \mapsto x - \sqrt{n}} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \int_{k-\sqrt{n}}^{k+1-\sqrt{n}} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \int_\R \chi_{\set{k-\sqrt{n} \leq x \leq k+1-\sqrt{n}}} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \int_\R \abs{f\p{x}} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \chi_{\set{k-x \leq \sqrt{n} \leq k+1-x}} \,\diff{x}. \end{aligned}∫kk+1​n=1∑∞​n​1​∣∣​f(x−n​)∣∣​dx​=n=1∑∞​n​1​∫kk+1​∣∣​f(x−n​)∣∣​dx=n=1∑∞​n​1​∫kk+1​∣∣​f(x−n​)∣∣​dx=n=1∑∞​n​1​∫k−n​k+1−n​​∣f(x)∣dx=n=1∑∞​n​1​∫R​χ{k−n​≤x≤k+1−n​}​∣f(x)∣dx=∫R​∣f(x)∣n=1∑∞​n​1​χ{k−x≤n​≤k+1−x}​dx.​(x↦x−n​)

To complete the proof, we will estimate the sum. Notice that because n≥1n \geq 1n≥1,

k−x≤n≤k+1−x  ⟹  max⁡ {1,k−x}≤n≤1+max⁡ {1,k−x}  ⟹  (max⁡ {1,k−x})2≤n≤(1+max⁡ {1,k−x})2.\begin{aligned} k - x \leq \sqrt{n} \leq k + 1 - x &\implies \max\,\set{1, k - x} \leq \sqrt{n} \leq 1 + \max\,\set{1, k - x} \\ &\implies \p{\max\,\set{1, k - x}}^2 \leq n \leq \p{1 + \max\,\set{1, k - x}}^2. \end{aligned}k−x≤n​≤k+1−x​⟹max{1,k−x}≤n​≤1+max{1,k−x}⟹(max{1,k−x})2≤n≤(1+max{1,k−x})2.​

Thus, for each xxx, there are at most

(1+max⁡ {1,k−x})2−(max⁡ {1,k−x})2+1=2max⁡ {1,k−x}+2\p{1 + \max\,\set{1, k - x}}^2 - \p{\max\,\set{1, k - x}}^2 + 1 = 2\max\,\set{1, k - x} + 2(1+max{1,k−x})2−(max{1,k−x})2+1=2max{1,k−x}+2

non-zero terms in the sum. Hence,

∫kk+1∑n=1∞1n∣f(x−n)∣ dx≤∫R∣f(x)∣2max⁡ {1,k−x}+2max⁡ {1,k−x} dx≤4∥f∥L1,\int_k^{k+1} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \abs{f\p{x - \sqrt{n}}} \,\diff{x} \leq \int_\R \abs{f\p{x}} \frac{2\max\,\set{1, k - x} + 2}{\max\,\set{1, k - x}} \,\diff{x} \leq 4\norm{f}_{L^1},∫kk+1​n=1∑∞​n​1​∣∣​f(x−n​)∣∣​dx≤∫R​∣f(x)∣max{1,k−x}2max{1,k−x}+2​dx≤4∥f∥L1​,

so the sum converges absolutely for almost every x∈[k,k+1]x \in \br{k, k+1}x∈[k,k+1]. Since kkk is arbitrary, it follows that the sum converges absolutely almost everywhere.
